ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
N/A
n/a
online lecture, online lab, online seminar -- great fusion
Combination of lecture and discussion.
Certain days were set aside for an in-class lab to go through data analysis skills in R with a small group of classmates. There was also one virtual guest lecture.

Measuring Impact alternated between two formats: a leminar-style class (which was open to participation since there were fewer than 20 people in the class) and coding labs in R that were done entirely in small breakout groups. The labs are low-commitment and entirely to apply your understanding to datasets in the real world.
Class lectures combined with in-class labs using RStudio w/ discussions afterward
The course was non-recorded, live lectures and available office hours with the TA and Professor!
Most of the classes were more lecture style, but we did have days in which the class was organized much more as a seminar, with lots of student discussion.
Assigned readings.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Real world field experiments, learn how to critique literature on experiments.
Learned how to identify and measure bias, especially in field experiments

I learned about field experiment design, and how to handle the experiment implementation and analysis when things go wrong. Of the stats classes I've taken, Measuring Impact covered the applications that I'm most interested in. I enjoyed the class!

I learned about effective field experiment and survey design and how to analyze the results of a field experiment. We covered topics like treatment effect heterogeneity, blocking, clustering, and more. Professor Kalla made sure to include real world examples which really helped with my understanding of the topics.
How to run a field experiment.
Understanding how to build a feasible and useful field experiment
I learned a lot about randomized experiments and how to run tests effectively
Learned what a field experiment is, how to create one from scratch, identify potential problems to consider when running data analysis, and interpret results

Measuring Impact as a class on the analysis behind (and implementation of) randomized experiments. The problem sets were a mix of hand/R calculations and how to conceptually assess experiments. For our final project, we were able to conduct our own field experiment.
I learned how to analyze and conduct randomized experiments.

Design of randomized field experiments, as well as how to analyze them and interpret/discuss results; data analysis using R; how to determine causal impact of interventions (such as canvassing techniques, advertisements, etc.); reading and interpreting reports about field experiments

This course teaches a lot about real-world applications and tools for data science and field experimentation. Beyond learning the stats and technical skills required to effectively run experiments and do analysis, this course really teaches you how to apply those learnings to projects and studies.

I definitely improved of my statistical knowledge during the class, as well as learning a lot about field experiments. The final project running our own experiment definitely helped apply the in class concepts to work driven by us students.
How to conduct and analyze randomized field experiments, and deal with issues like noncompliance.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Professor Kalla and Drew -- love them both! Content was also very interesting; Weaknesses: Maybe more support in class on how to do some of the coding, but pretty good overall

The textbook was helpful and I appreciated how closely Prof. Kalla followed along with the readings he assigned. The labs were great for practicing analyzing real experimental data in R. I enjoyed the guest lecture at the end of the semester. I think it would be nice if in future Zoom or in person semesters, the professor offered open office hours where students could learn from each others' questions, instead of only having hours by appointment.

I liked that the class was a seminar, it felt very intimate and engaging. The problem sets were helpful to understand the material we were learning in class. I wish we had been given some more guidance as to what the midterms would look like, but I think Professor Kalla did a good job at preparing us for them.

Strength - professor
Weakness - challenging midterms, but such is life.

A strength of this course was the Professor. Kalla and Drew are very knowledgeable in this field and explained everything very well. A way this course could improve is improving the quality of the psets. I sometimes felt like the psets did not correlate with what we were learning. (Theres 5 in total)
Great course, I learned a lot about the subject materials and the group project was rewarding.

Strengths: The people! Professor Kalla and Drew (TF) created a classroom environment that was very open and welcoming to people with varying statistical and R skill backgrounds. Classmates were also engaging and the material was fascinating. There were also clear expectations set on how to participate, turn in assignments, and engage with the class material.

Weaknesses: The midterm exams were a bit rough because we were still getting used to having a time restriction on what we were doing during class, lab, and homework without a time limit.

Overall, the class was very engaging and accommodating in this hectic semester. A final project instead of a final exam was a good touch to show us how field experiments work in the real world. In terms of weaknesses, I think there could be a little more connection between the problem sets and what we see in class. The lectures and discussion were very theory-based and qualitative while the problem sets were very calculation-heavy. I know this may not be the intention of the course, but I would want to see the problem sets be more of a reflection of what's taught in the lectures, based on analyzing experiments qualitatively (this is coming from a math nerd).
This is a very well taught and useful course. The lectures and slides were very clear and Professor Kalla and the TA Drew did a great job at answering questions.

Strengths: I like that it is a seminar-sized class (20ish people) even though most instruction is in a lecture-style format. It allows for more individualized attention as well as a more tightly-knit class, which is useful for collaboration and such. The labs were a great way to solidify knowledge of the concepts that we learned in class, as well as give us a chance to work closely together and learn from each other; I especially appreciated this because of the virtual nature of this semester. The PSets were a bit difficult earlier in the semester, but appropriately adjusted in difficulty later on, and I appreciated that Prof. Kalla dropped our lowest grade. 

Weaknesses: Could have used more information the midterm exam beforehand, though it was curved well in the end

I loved that this course was a seminar: it really allowed every student to understand the different components of the course. I also appreciated how the prof and TA were so available to help and support students, and in-class labs really helped us learn how to apply techniques from lecture, and made the course much more interactive, On the opposite end, Psets were definitely a challenge (though there were only 5 of them total). The strengths, though, definitely out-weighted the weaknesses. A great course, and the prof did a terrific job of adapting it to the virtual world!
I thought the class was impeccably run. Prof Kalla was organized, gave good lectures, and was very available outside of class.

Strengths: Lectures closely followed the textbook. Problem sets were appropriately challenging. Interesting concepts and cases. Good pace, and COVID-flexible. Group final project instead of final exam.
Weakness: Midterm exams were difficult to complete in the time allotted, but grades were curved nicely.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the lecture/discussion style was pretty good, though I wish it could've been recorded (though understandably it wasn't for the sake of students' privacy).

It was an interesting challenge to do a field experiment entirely online. I thought the project was a good way to get to know other students in the class and adapt experimental methods to the pandemic environment.
Professor Kalla made it very clear that he was understanding that we are all learning during a pandemic and was very accommodating of people's situations. I appreciated this a lot.

This class is a top-notch example of what a class during a pandemic should look like. Professor and TF were accommodating, always available for help, and understanding that sometimes, life just happens. Professor Kalla was patient and a quick problem solver when tech went wrong and used the hand-raising function in class so efficiently to call on people during class so that there were no awkward silences nor people struggling to ask the questions that they wanted to ask at any time.

I feel like the improvements that could be done are in the mechanics of the final project. If more resources were given to students when conducting their field experiments, it could lead to a more diverse array of final projects. Other than that Professor Kalla was AMAZING for the entirety of this semester with accommodations and checking in.
The seminar style discussion was facilitated well on zoom.
See question 4 (strengths and weaknesses); having office hour availability for the TA Drew and Professor Kalla was also helpful. Prof. was very kind and accommodating in general.

The course was really great virtually! The seminar style allowed for lots of conversation and Q&A, and in-class labs in breakout rooms really allowed students to interact with other and work together to better understand the material. Overall, a terrific course online (probably just as good in person).

I think the group projects were a good way to get students in the class to engage together with the course material. It definitely helped spur student to student engagement in a semester that had relatively few opportunities to do so.

Synchronous with cameras on felt like a real class! Asking questions of the students encouraged participation. However, while lab breakout rooms fostered some discussion between students, most of the time was spent coding individually, and the labs were often too long to finish in time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I think Prof. Kalla and Drew, our TF, were both very helpful.
Yes! Kalla was a wonderful professor and I learned a lot in this course. Great if you want a statistics elective, to learn more about R, or better understand the nuances that go into studies IRL

Yeah! I think this is a great S&DS elective. Professor Kalla is a nice guy who does cool research with progressive political organizations. If you are interested in political campaigns/polling/any type of social science field experiments, this is a good class.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in statistics and/or politics. Professor Kalla is amazing and the material is engaging and I always looked forward to going to class.
Yes. Useful topic. Kalla is great.
Yes if you want to understand experimental design and interpretation specifically.
I would recommend this course to another student. I truly feel like I was able to take what I learned and apply it in research.
If you are remotely interested in what experiments in the real world look like, take this class! Highly recommend!

I would recommend this course to a fellow student in ANY circumstance. I think Prof. Kalla was so good at handling virtual learning that I would recommend this course even more during a COVID semester (should this class be offered again under these circumstances).
Randomized experiments are important in almost every field. While most (not all) of the focus in the class is on politicial science field experiments, you can use the same theory in any other field.

Definitely! Professor Kalla is fantastic, and though it is billed as a political science course crosslisted with S&DS, the knowledge from this course is useful across a broad range of social sciences. I personally took it for the S&DS certificate, so to anyone else pursuing it this is an excellent elective choice. Top tier professor, top tier course!

10/10 would recommend - a great stats course, and the fact that it is a seminar makes it a rare find. Would definitely recommend to stats and polisci students wanting to learn about experimentation, and real world stats applications!
Yes, I would absolutely recommend. The class meshes statistics and data science really well, while also including many applications and real-world examples.
Yes! Despite COVID, it was one of my favorites at Yale. Interesting and not too hard or too easy.
